content:
FOMC

FOMC left rates unchanged at 1.50%-1.75% as expected via unanimous decision and sees no change of rates in 2020, while it maintained IOER at 1.55% and said current policy stance is appropriate to maintain the US economic expansion, inflation and employment goals. (Newswires)

Fed dropped its language from statement regarding uncertainties about the outlook remaining and said it will continue to monitor incoming data, including global developments and muted inflation pressures. Fed repeated job gains are solid, and inflation is still below target but also reiterated that business fixed investment and exports remain weak.

FOMC maintained GDP growth forecasts across all horizons with 2019 seen at 2.2%, 2020 at 2.0%, 2021 at 1.9%, 2022 at 1.8% and longer-run at 1.9%, while it projected appropriate policy path for 2019 at 1.6% (Prev. 1.9%), 2020 at 1.6% (Prev. 1.9%), 2021 at 1.9% (prev. 2.1%), 2022 at 2.1% (prev. 2.4%) and longer-run at 2.5% (prev. 2.5%).

Fed Chair Powell said US economic outlook is a favourable one and that policy is not on a pre-set course, while he added that current monetary policy somewhat accommodative. Powell also reiterated that a persistent move higher in inflation would have to be seen in order for rate hikes and noted it has been very challenging to get inflation to the 2% target.

Initial reaction was rather stale however as the dust settled markets took it as a dovish meeting which put further pressure on the greenback sending the Dollar Index (DXY) to session lows. S&P 500 caught a slight bid which put the bourses back at the top end of the daily range just above the 3140 mark. Yields also lowered finding support at the 1.8% mark, a level it resides heading into Asia trade and money market price. The direction of moves in assets continued its direction as Powell’s presser went underway with participants paying attention to his comment that there is a great struggle to get inflation to the 2% target, suggesting inflation will be around current levels for some time. 

 

ASIA-PAC

China Global Times Opinion piece noted that China is not Mexico and that It's impossible for the US to strike a trade deal with China by forcing Beijing to make big compromises, as the US did to Mexico when it came to the USMCA. Furthermore, China Global Times had also tweeted that US brinkmanship in using tariffs as a leverage for forcing China into conceding further ground in trade talks will not be successful and could prompt further tit-for-tat tariffs. (Twitter)

CNBC’s Yoon tweeted Chinese experts who follow trade talks said China would want December 15 tariffs cancelled as a minimum pre-condition for continued negotiations of a phase one deal and suggested that if not, it would be a sign US is not serious. (Twitter)

Chinese trade experts noted that if US President Trump does not cancel planned tariffs on Chinese products on December 15th, it will hurt US more than China as China has digested the possibility and is well prepared to cope. (Twitter)

 

UK/EU

UK Election BMG/Independent poll showed Conservatives at 41% and Labour at 32%, both unchanged. (Newswires)

UK Election Panelbase poll showed Conservatives at 43% and Labour at 34%, both unchanged. (Newswires)

UK Election Opinium poll showed Conservative at 45% (-1) and Labour at 33% (+2). (Newswires)

UK Election: Savanta/ComRes poll puts Conservatives at 41% (unch.) and Labour at 36% (+3). (Newswires)

ECB said that its Governing Council does not object to the appointment of Germany's Isabel Schnabel to the board. (Newswires)

Spanish PM Sanchez will accept the King's invitation to form a new government. (Newswires) 

 

COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks w/e 0.822M vs. Exp. -2.763M (Prev. -4.856M). (Newswires)

OPEC Monthly Oil Report stated 2019 world oil demand growth forecast unchanged from the prior report at 980k BPD and 2020 world oil demand is forecast to increase 1.08mln BPD Y/Y which is also unchanged from the prior report, while preliminary data indicated that global oil supply in November increased by 410k BPD to average 99.78mln BPD (Prev. 99.78mln BPD). (Newswires) 

 

GEOPOLITICS

US Senate Foreign Relations Committee advanced Turkey sanctions over objections from the administration by a vote of 18 to 4. (Newswires)

 

US

  • US CPI (Nov) M/M 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.4%). (Newswires)
  • US CPI (Nov) Y/Y 2.1% vs. Exp. 2.0% (Prev. 1.8%)

 

MARKET RECAP

Boeing (BA) weighed on the DJIA after the FAA said the 737 MAX will not fly in 2019. Home Depot (HD) gave its FY sales growth view beneath what analysts had expected. GameStop (GME) took a double-digit haircut after a surprise loss in its earnings report, in addition to dismal guidance. Netflix (NFLX) pared some of Tuesday’s losses on a positive mention at Piper Jaffray, although it came under pressure on reports it was offering discount prices to multi-month subscribers. Tesla (TSLA) was bid on sources reporting it would be increasing its Model 3 prices in China. Freeport-McMoRan (FCX) and Vale (VALE) benefitted from stronger metals prices, with the latter also upgraded to Buy from Hold at Jefferies. Jack Henry (JKHY) dipped on a downgrade to Underperform from In Line at Evercore. Semiconductors (MU, WDC, AMAT, QCOM, SOX) helped the Nasdaq outperform the other major bourses. LogMeIn (LOGM) surged on reports it could be bought out by Elliott. JetBlue (JBLU) traded lower on a Q4 guidance cut. SPX +0.28% at 3141, NDX up 0.44% at 8655, DJIA +0.1% at 27,911.

The TPLEX made gains on Wednesday, working off a weaker Dollar and extending after the FOMC rate decision. As the dollar weakened heading into the US session, the yields followed suit, with the curve initially bull-flattening, although, after the FOMC stood pat and abated any expectations of a hawkish tilt, the short-end caught up, with yields settling across the curve by approximately 4bps. US T-note (H0) futures settled 11+ ticks higher at 129-09.

subject: Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 11th December 2019: Rates left unchanged whilst Fed stresses inflation woes; USD hits 4-month low
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries up, Crude down, Dollar down
  • REAR VIEW: Fed leaves rates unchanged, no hawkish surprise; Navarro says no decision on Dec 15th tariffs; CPI slightly beats
  • COMING UP: Events: UK Election, ECB, SNB, CBRT; Data: US PPI, Tankan Manufacturing Survey; Speakers: ECB’s Lagarde, BOC’s Poloz

and BOC’s Poloz

* MARKET WRAP: US equities traded sideways overnight ahead although White House Trade Advisor Navarro echoed what we heard from Kudlow that the is no indication that the December tariffs will not be implemented, adding that China is trying to shape the narrative. Throughout the morning and afternoon newsflow was thin as were ranges as participants awaited the FOMC and its latest Summary of Economic Projections. Initial reaction was rather stale however as the dust settled markets took it as a dovish meeting which put further pressure on the greenback sending the Dollar Index (DXY) to session lows. S&P 500 caught a slight bid which put the bourses back at the top end of the daily range just above the 3140 mark. Yields also lowered finding support at the 1.8% mark, a level it resides heading into Asia trade and money market price. The direction of moves in assets continued its direction as Powell’s presser went underway with participants paying attention to his comment that there is a great struggle to get inflation to the 2% target, suggesting inflation will be around current levels for some time.

* FED: FOMC unanimously opted to maintain the federal funds target range between 1.50-1.75%, as had been overwhelming expected by both analysts and money markets; the IOER was also maintained at 1.55% (some had expected a ‘technical’ hike). For the most part, the statement was little changed, describing job gains as “solid” and inflation still “below target”; however, it did remain the reference from the statement about ‘uncertainties about this outlook remain’. The ‘dot plot’ appears to have been a mark-to-market affair, with the 2019 dot coming in line with where rates currently are, and like the September projections, the Fed still sees one hike in 2021 and one hike in 2022, while its longer-term dot was unchanged at 2.5%. GDP and inflation forecasts were unchanged (core PCE was revised lower for 2019), though the jobless rate forecast was lowered slightly. The Fed reiterated its data-dependent approach, saying it will continue to monitor incoming data and global developments. Short-term rate futures were little changed after the rate decision.

* POWELL PRESS CONFERENCE: Fed Chair Powell retained his upbeat view of the US economy, highlighting the familiar risks of sluggish global growth and trade tensions which are weighing on it. He suggested that the Fed’s insurance rate cuts had kept the US economic outlook on track and policy was now “somewhat accommodative”. In terms of the outlook, Powell reiterated that the stance of monetary policy will likely remain appropriate as long as incoming data held up, also reiterating that the Fed would respond accordingly to material changes in the outlook. Powell was asked whether the Fed could ‘take back’ the insurance rate cuts it has implemented; he said that three rate cuts was not part of the plan when the Fed began the insurance cuts, and that the need for rate hikes was less than what it was in the mid-1990s cycle. Powell also reiterated that the Fed would need to see a significant, persistent move higher in inflation before it lifted rates. He also stated that it is very challenging to get inflation back to 2%, which saw USD weaken, stocks, gold and T-Notes rise during the press conference (with the implication seemingly that rates may need to remain lower for longer to help the Fed reach its inflation goal). (In wake of these remarks, some commentators highlighted remarks from Powell last year, where he seemed comfortable that inflation was moving to target, and at that stage, Powell did not feel that policy needed to be accommodative). On wage growth, Powell said it was being held back by low productivity and globalisation, adding that the labour market might not be as tight as the FOMC had previously thought. With regards to repo markets, Powell again sought to play down the link between money market operations and monetary policy, saying repo-ops were unlikely to have any macroeconomic implications; he said pressures in recent weeks had been subdued, and the Fed stands ready to adjust operations to keep the EFFR within range. Powell also noted that historically, repo markets face pressure towards year-end, though the Fed chair suggested that he did not foresee any unmanageable stress, and the Fed stood ready to adjust its operations as appropriate, though he played down the notion that this was forthcoming, stating that operations were currently proceeding well.

* US CPI: Headline CPI rose +0.3% M/M (exp. +0.2%), and +2.1% Y/Y, rising from the prior +1.8% Y/Y, and above the expected +2.0%. The core rates were unchanged at 2.3% Y/Y (rising +0.2% M/M, in line with the previous pace). "Overall, core CPI inflation is trending at about 2.25%, but the Y/Y rate will rise in the first half of next year due to a combination of base effects, tariff pass-through and, perhaps, sustained upward pressure in healthcare services," Pantheon Macroeconomics said, "nothing very terrible is likely, but core inflation could easily hit 2.5% by early spring, for the first time since September 2008."

* US/CHINA: Overnight, White House trade advisor Navarro said no decision had yet been made on delaying the planned 15th December tariff hikes on around USD 160bln of Chinese imports. Ultimately, the news was not particularly new (NEC director Kudlow and Ags Sec Perdue had both this week suggested that Trump was yet to make a decision).

* ECB PREVIEW: ECB Monetary Policy Decision Due At 12:45GMT, (13:45CET, 07:45ET), On Thursday 12th December 2019, Press Conference Due At 13:30GMT, (14:30CET, 08:30ET). Christine Lagarde's first meeting as ECB President is not expected to deliver any material changes to current monetary policy settings, given that the September easing measures are yet to take full effect, and there is no urgency to add further accommodation at this stage as the ECB assesses the impact of its September easing. The focus will therefore fall on how Lagarde intends to run the central bank, and its upcoming strategic policy review, which will likely be formally announced at the December confab; but there is a risk that this meeting will be light on details, which may possibly result in horizontal price action. Many believe Lagarde's first task will be uniting a divided Governing Council, where there are mixed views on the efficacy and risks of loose(r) policy, as well as the practicalities of the ECB’s decision-making functions. Lagarde is also expected to reiterate her call on fiscal authorities to do more to support the Eurozone economy. Elsewhere, updated economic projections may see near-term growth forecasts nudged up slightly, though further forecasts are subject to downside risks; inflation forecasts are seen little changed. (Click here for full preview)

* YOUGOV MRP MODEL: The final MRP Model forecasted a narrower conservative majority than the previous, seeing conservatives with a 28-seat majority, lower than the previous expectation for a 68-seat majority. However, the pollster highlighted a margin of error in the model with seats ranging between 311-367 seats out of the total 650. With the UK election just two days away, pollsters will continue to release polls up until midnight of tomorrow, given they are not allowed to publish them on election day itself. For a full Newsquawk preview of the UK election, please click here.

* NORTH KOREA: US is reportedly in discussions to plan a meeting between US Special Representative for North Korea and a North Korean Official next week in the demilitarised zone, according to a South Korean Lawmaker. The apparent meeting comes after this weekend missile reports from NK and rather punch language from both the US and North Korea. Stratfor’s analysts highlight this meeting could potentially prevent a breakdown in talks as there are worries North Korea may withdraw from negotiations with the States. With the geopolitical consultancy highlighting the US would likely have to offer significant concession to the region, potentially providing NK with sanction relief. It was also reported that the US Envoy to UN Craft stated that the US is prepared to be flexible in talks with North Korea, adds US remains ready to take actions in parallel and to simultaneously take concrete steps towards a denuclearisation deal with North Korea, however they must make the decision to worth with the US.

* FRANCE PENSION REFORM: French PM Philippe unveiled the government's proposals for pension reforms on Wednesday. the PM said the retirement age would remain at 62 years old, though the reforms will introduce incentives for French citizens to retire at 64 by 2027. Unions did not welcome the proposals, with some officials suggesting that further strike actions could follow in the coming days. Analysts at Stratfor explain that the French government is seeking to strike a balance between preserving the main tenets of its pension reform and introducing some enticements to make it easier for protesters to accept the plan. Unions and others have been protesting for a week in response to proposals by the government to replace France's multiple pension systems with a single, unified scheme. However, workers fear that the new system will eliminate their current benefits and force them to work longer before retiring, Stratfor said.

* EUROPEAN COUNCIL (12-13th Dec): EU leaders will look at several issues, including the EU's long-term budget and climate change. The meeting will be the first EU summit chaired by Charles Michel since he was elected EC President. EU heads of state or government will discuss a proposed budget of EUR 1.087trln for 2021-2027, equal to 1.07% of the gross national income of EU member states.

* FED POMO: The Fed will on Thursday publish a new monthly POMO schedule on Thursday, expected to show it will continue purchasing T-bills at a monthly rate of USD 60bln. "The best short USD trade on POMO-days seems to be against SEK so far," Nordea's FX strategists write, "but USD patterns on days when the [NY Fed market desk] buys USD 7.25bln worth of T-bills are still muddy."

* ECB TLTRO-3: Additionally, Thursday also sees the second allotment-date in the ECB's TLTRO-3. Watch the take-up – Nordea suggests that the data might start to matter for the EUR liquidity outlook. “An uptake above the EUR 338bln that matures in the TLTRO-2 in June would be needed for the uptake to be seen as a EUR liquidity addition (which would be EURUSD negative, EUR rates negative, etc),” adding “we lean towards a higher uptake as the hoarding of EUR liquidity ahead of the tiering implementation showcased that parts of the Euro system needed further liquidity in the new 6x MRR [minimum reserve requirement] exemption world,” and adds that it is usually a decent idea to be short EUR over the coming month if a big EUR liquidity uptake is seen.

* WTI (F0) SETTLED USD 0.48 LOWER AT USD 58.76/BBL; BRENT (G0) SETTLED USD 0.62 LOWER AT USD 63.72/BBL. Crude benchmarks traded lower amid inventories reporting surprise build in crude stocks and lack of risk appetite. The EIA confirmed the surprise build in crude stocks (+0.8mln vs. exp. -2.8mln) indicated on Tuesday by the API, whilst Cushing reported a large draw of 3.4mln and Us production notched 100k lower to 12.8mln BPD; in the products, both distillates and gasoline printed much larger than expected builds, deepening the wound. Elsewhere in the EIA report, refinery utilization printed a surprise contraction and net imports increased by 634k BPD to 3.487mln BPD, with both imports and exports rising, although the former more acutely. The OPEC Monthly Report didn't provide much impetus for price movement, but analysts were noting the bullish production figures ahead of the new cuts. Also of note, desks are encouraged that Brent remains near USD 64/bbl, which can be seen as a positive from the outcome of the OPEC meetings last week.

* OPEC MONTHLY OIL REPORT: 2019 and 2020 oil demand growth remained unchanged at 980k BPD and 1.08mln BPD, respectively, whilst OPEC crude production fell by 193k BPD in November to 29.55mln BPD. Oil output increased mostly in Ecuador, Kuwait and Libya, while production decreased in Saudi Arabia, Angola, Iraq and Iran. The share of OPEC crude oil in total global production decreased by 0.3ppts to 29.6% in November 2019 compared to the previous month. There is a slight contrast to the EIA STEO, which saw the 2019 world oil demand view unchanged but raised its 2020 forecast by 50k BPD to 1.42mln BPD. OPEC believes that US oil demand will likely be solid throughout the remainder of the year, whilst EIA noted that US production will likely continue to grow as rig efficacy offsets declining rig activity.

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +0.28% at 3141, NDX up 0.44% at 8655, DJIA +0.1% at 27,911

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Boeing (BA) weighed on the DJIA after the FAA said the 737 MAX will not fly in 2019. Home Depot (HD) gave its FY sales growth view beneath what analysts had expected. GameStop (GME) took a double-digit haircut after a surprise loss in its earnings report, in addition to dismal guidance. Netflix (NFLX) pared some of Tuesday’s losses on a positive mention at Piper Jaffray, although it came under pressure on reports it was offering discount prices to multi-month subscribers. Tesla (TSLA) was bid on sources reporting it would be increasing its Model 3 prices in China. Freeport-McMoRan (FCX) and Vale (VALE) benefitted from stronger metals prices, with the latter also upgraded to Buy from Hold at Jefferies. Jack Henry (JKHY) dipped on a downgrade to Underperform from In Line at Evercore. Semiconductors (MU, WDC, AMAT, QCOM, SOX) helped the Nasdaq outperform the other major bourses. LogMeIn (LOGM) surged on reports it could be bought out by Elliott. JetBlue (JBLU) traded lower on a Q4 guidance cut.

* US T-NOTE (H0) FUTURES SETTLE 11+ TICKS HIGHER AT 129-09. The TPLEX made gains on Wednesday, working off a weaker Dollar and extending after the FOMC rate decision. As the dollar weakened heading into the US session, the yields followed suit, with the curve initially bull-flattening, although, after the FOMC stood pat and abated any expectations of a hawkish tilt, the short-end caught up, with yields settling across the curve by approximately 4bps.

* USD: The buck continued its recent trend lower today hitting a 4 month low after selling was exacerbated by the Federal Reserve’s latest interest rate decision and Fed Chair Powell’s press conference, after comments where the Fed chair talked about the difficulties of bringing inflation to target, with traders reasoning that rate may need to be lower for longer in order to boost price pressures.

* CAD: The Loonie strengthened a fair bit on Wednesday with USDCAD trading from highs of 1.3240 to lows of 1.3176 without a fresh catalyst, however a potential follow through from USMCA comments could be helping the Loonie, plus a weak dollar today is also weighing on the cross. USDCAD has very almost pared back its move on Friday which saw the cross rise from 1.3175 to highs of 1.3270 driven by a double edged sword, a strong US jobs report and weak Canadian jobs report, with the currency pair trading around the 1.3185 mark at pixel time.

* GBP: Was firmer to end the day despite seeing initial defensiveness post the YouGov MRP poll which saw a Tory majority of 28 (its previous forecast in November was a majority of 68), or a 9 point lead over Labour (vs 11 in the November MRP) -- within the margin of error for a hung Parliament (which is generally seen around a 7-point lead). The ultimate size of the majority will be the key catalyst for GBP in the weeks ahead, with desks suggesting a thinner margin allows more uncertainty to enter, while a majority of around 20+ may be needed to quell fears. (It is worth noting that while many desks are highlighting the downside, and risks of a hung parliament, YouGov itself noted that the margin of error is very wide, and cannot rule out either a hung parliament or a large Tory majority, with the implied range forecasting Conservatives taking between 311-367 out of the 650 seats). GBPUSD however was firmer on the day given the broad dollar weakness which saw the cross breach 1.32 to the upside ahead of the election on Thursday.

* EUR: The single currency traded relatively flat against Sterling but firmer against the buck as the dollar continues to weaken this week, whilst the Euro continues its rise. EURUSD tested 1.1150 to the upside however failed to breach the level on Wednesday trade despite dollar selling in the aftermath of the FOMC.

* JPY, XAU, CHF: Havens were genuinely bid, spurred by the latest Fed decision and press conference with USDJPY breaching 108.50 to the downside, a level it resides at heading into the overnight session. US yields were also falling during/post Fed; therefore, rate differentials may also be playing a part to the JPY strength in the tail end of the session. XAU traded just shy of the 1480 mark at highs as the precious metal rallied thank to Fed Chair Powell. CHF traded firmer against the buck, however weaker against GBP and EUR, which were both firmer on the day.

* AUD, NZD: The Kiwi government announced an additional NZD 12bln of spending earlier today, which will mostly be allocated to infrastructure spending. NZD is underperforming its Antipodean counterpart on Wednesday, though analysts remind us that the run of NZ data has been decent lately.

* EMFX (ZAR, BRL, MXN, TRY): ZAR: Load shedding has ratcheted up this week; the more power outages, the more intense the likely impact on South Africa's economic output. Mining companies have been forced to shut underground operations and processing facilities, as a result. Analysts note that the mining sector last saw outages this intense in 2008, which saw many gold shafts closed, hitting both gold production and mining employment. UBS offers some context on the economic impact: the mining industry contributes around 7.3% of GDP, ZAR 30bln towards government revenues and taxes, and employs 450k people, and it adds that although on Monday Eskom downgraded load-shedding, further capacity constraints are probable given widespread technical problems at coal plants. BRL: The Real traded firmer against the buck today driven by further dollar weakness and as participants await tonight’s Selic Rate decision, where the BCB is expected to cut by 50bps after market to 4.50% - it would be the fourth straight meeting of cuts. Some analysts are expecting the BCB to signal the end of the easing cycle -- short of this would be a dovish surprise. Desks think a '50bps cut and done' could be a positive for the BRL. MXN also traded firmer today amid the broad dollar weakness, however TRY traded flat amid ongoing S-400 concerns where turkey announced the sanctions would not prevent it using the missile defence system, a move likely unwelcomed by the US.

*  SEK, NOK: Firmer after higher than expected inflation (CPIF +0.1% M/M vs. exp. 0.0; +1.7% Y/Y vs. exp. 1.6%) which some believe raises the risk of a Riksbank hike next week. NOK is struggling to recover after the soft regional surveys out earlier in the week. Some desks have sought to add NOKSEK longs after the soft SEK inflation data.

* BCB PRIMER: Brazil’s Central Bank Selic Rate decision is scheduled for release at 20:00 GMT/ 15:00 ET today, where analysts are looking for a fourth consecutive 50bp cut.  Some analysts are expecting the BCB to signal the end of the easing cycle -- short of this would be a dovish surprise. Desks think a '50bps cut and done' could be a positive for the BRL. Recently USDBRL has touched record lows causing the central bank to intervene in the FX market by selling dollars therefore any commentary surrounding the BRL weakness will be eyed. Analysts at IGM highlight that participants questioned whether further easing would be implemented after the recent intervention as the two are considered incompatible. Recent data has been strong, with GDP printing firmer than expected both M/M and Y/Y, which IGM highlights it initially saw some unwinding of market pricing for further easing in the future, although since the BRL has strengthened since the intervention, pricing returned to original levels and price in a 50bps cut for today and a further 25bps cut in February. November’s inflation was also firmer than expected at 3.27% Y/Y and 0.51% M/M, BCB’s current inflation targets are 4.25% for 2019, 4% for 2020, 3.75% for 2021 and 3.5% for 2022, however the bank allows a 1.5% leeway either side therefore currently CPI is sitting within the tolerance range of 2.75-5.75%.

* ISRAEL: Country may face its third election within the last 12 months after its parliament was given until midnight today to find a lawmaker that could form a coalition, after PM Netanyahu and Gantz were unable to do so. "Currently there’s been no sign of a breakthrough, and if the stalemate isn’t resolved by the deadline, parliament will set a 2nd March election date and dissolve," UBS says, "A bill to disband the legislature has already been submitted, and parliament scheduled to debate it this morning." It was later reported that its parliament began rushing through a bill to call a third general election as the talks between Netanyahu and rival Gantz broke down ahead of the midnight deadline. In terms of a date for the third election in a year, DPA reported Netanyahu is under increasing pressure to hold a leadership primary on December 26th.

* SNB PREVIEW: The SNB are expected to leave rates unchanged at -0.75% on Thursday with all 37 contributors surveyed by Reuters forecasting no rate change. Focus for the meeting will be on the small potential for a rate cut and any alterations to the Bank’s language around the CHF either in the report or from Governor Jordan in the subsequent press conference. Recent data prints out of Switzerland are, on balance, painting a down beat picture for the domestic economy; though this is not seen as sufficient to prompt policy action via a rate cut. Commentary since September has largely been reiterations of the SNB’s language around the CHF and willingness to intervene; the most pertinent comments stemmed from Chief Economist Lenz (non-voter) who noted the Bank has additional room for rate cuts, with further cuts ‘not ruled out’. (Click here for link)

* CBRT PREVIEW: The consensus among analysts points to the Turkey’s Central Bank cutting its Repo Rate by 150bps to 12.50%, while money markets price 108bps worth of easing. As usual, the magnitude of the rate move tends to be unorthodox; the October cut of 250bps was also deeper than expectations at the time. House views unsurprisingly reflect a split; TD Securities expects a 175bps reduction, while ING sees a more modest 100bps cut – the former citing lower global rates, and the latter a seeming end to the front-loading of rate cuts. ANALYSIS: POWELL PRESS CONFERENCE - Powell again sticks to the script, though highlighted the difficulties in getting inflation to target, and thinks the labour market might have more slack than previously estimated
analysis_details: Fed Chair Powell retained his upbeat view of the US economy, highlighting the familiar risks of sluggish global growth and trade tensions which are weighing on it. He suggested that the Fed’s insurance rate cuts had kept the US economic outlook on track and policy was now “somewhat accommodative”. In terms of the outlook, Powell reiterated that the stance of monetary policy will likely remain appropriate as long as incoming data held up, also reiterating that the Fed would respond accordingly to material changes in the outlook. Powell was asked whether the Fed could ‘take back’ the insurance rate cuts it has implemented; he said that three rate cuts was not part of the plan when the Fed began the insurance cuts, and that the need for rate hikes was less than what it was in the mid-1990s cycle. Powell also reiterated that the Fed would need to see a significant, persistent move higher in inflation before it lifted rates. He also stated that it is very challenging to get inflation back to 2%, which saw USD weaken, stocks, gold and T-Notes rise during the press conference (with the implication seemingly that rates may need to remain lower for longer to help the Fed reach its inflation goal). (In wake of these remarks, some commentators highlighted remarks from Powell last year, where he seemed comfortable that inflation was moving to target, and at that stage, Powell did not feel that policy needed to be accommodative). On wage growth, Powell said it was being held back by low productivity and globalisation, adding that the labour market might not be as tight as the FOMC had previously thought. With regards to repo markets, Powell again sought to play down the link between money market operations and monetary policy, saying reop ops were unlikely to have any macroeconomic implications; he said pressures in recent weeks had been subdued, and the Fed stands ready to adjust operations to keep the EFFR within range. Powell also noted that historically, repo markets face pressure towards year-end, though the Fed chair suggested that he did not foresee any unmanageable stress, and the Fed stood ready to adjust its operations as appropriate, though he played down the notion that this was forthcoming, stating that operations were currently proceeding well.

analysis_details:
CRUDE: Crude benchmarks traded lower amid inventories reporting surprise build in crude stocks and lack of risk appetite. The EIA confirmed the surprise build in crude stocks (+0.8mln vs. exp. -2.8mln) indicated on Tuesday by the API, whilst Cushing reported a large draw of 3.4mln and Us production notched 100k lower to 12.8mln BPD; in the products, both distillates and gasoline printed much larger than expected builds, deepening the wound. Elsewhere in the EIA report, refinery utilization printed a surprise contraction and net imports increased by 634k BPD to 3.487mln BPD, with both imports and exports rising, although the former more acutely. The OPEC Monthly Report didn't provide much impetus for price movement, but analysts were noting the bullish production figures ahead of the new cuts. Also of note, desks are encouraged that Brent remains near USD 64/bbl, which can be seen as a positive from the outcome of the OPEC meetings last week.

* OPEC MONTHLY OIL REPORT: 2019 and 2020 oil demand growth remained unchanged at 980k BPD and 1.08mln BPD, respectively, whilst OPEC crude production fell by 193k BPD in November to 29.55mln BPD. Oil output increased mostly in Ecuador, Kuwait and Libya, while production decreased in Saudi Arabia, Angola, Iraq and Iran. The share of OPEC crude oil in total global production decreased by 0.3ppts to 29.6% in November 2019 compared to the previous month. There is a slight contrast to the EIA STEO, which saw the 2019 world oil demand view unchanged but raised its 2020 forecast by 50k BPD to 1.42mln BPD. OPEC believes that US oil demand will likely be solid throughout the remainder of the year, whilst EIA noted that US production will likely continue to grow as rig efficacy offsets declining rig activity.

subject: FOMC SNAP ANALYSIS: Rate, statement, forecasts all as expected; little market move
analysis_details: FOMC unanimously opted to maintain the federal funds target range between 1.50-1.75%, as had been overwhelming expected by both analysts and money markets; the IOER was also maintained at 1.55% (some had expected a ‘technical’ hike). For the most part, the statement was little changed, describing job gains as “solid” and inflation still “below target”; however, it did remove the reference from the statement about ‘uncertainties about this outlook remain’. The ‘dot plot’ appears to have been a mark-to-market affair, with the 2019 dot coming in line with where rates currently are, and like the September projections, the Fed still sees one hike in 2021 and one hike in 2022, while its longer-term dot was unchanged at 2.5%. GDP and inflation forecasts were unchanged (core PCE was revised lower for 2019), though the jobless rate forecast was lowered slightly. The Fed reiterated its data-dependent approach, saying it will continue to monitor incoming data and global developments. Short-term rate futures were little changed after the rate decision.

analysis_details:
• JPMorgan is the largest holder of cash reserves in the banking system, and since the crisis, has been a frequent lender of next-to-last-resort, as banks avoid the Fed's Discount Window and Daylight Overdraft due to the regulatory stain that accompanies using them 
  • Analysts note JPMorgan's unwillingness to lend into the repo market is heavily influenced by regulatory restrictions with being too active in funding markets, which has gradually lead to a depleting amount of reserves available in the system leading to recent pressures
  • Year-end is a critical time for the repo market as banks look to secure funding; forward rates have been indicating around a 200bps surge in the repo rate across the turn of the year, something that is causing banks to take advantage of all the Fed's repo operations covering the period, which provides funding at the current rates within the FFR

Daily FX Wrap: CPI data dominates docket ahead of the Fed
content:
USD

A firmer than forecast headline US inflation read failed to provide the Dollar with any impetus in marked contrast to post-data developments in Sweden and South Africa. In fact, the DXY slipped back below 97.500 amidst widespread declines vs currency counterparts to retest yesterday’s lows as the clock ticks down to the last FOMC event of the year. The index is currently nearer the base of a relatively narrow 97.406-597 range awaiting fresh Fed policy guidance, SEP projections including the dot plots and Chair Powell’s presser that kick off at 19.0GMT and continue from 19.30GMT (see our Research Suite for a full preview).

SEK/AUD/NZD

The clear G10 outperformers, albeit to varying degrees, as the aforementioned Swedish CPI report essentially guaranteed that the Riksbank will deliver a well telegraphed 25 bp repo hike next Thursday. However, Aussie gains were mostly if not exclusively forged indirectly after the Kiwi reversed course in the wake of the NZ semi-annual fiscal outlook and budget balance showing an extra Nzd12 bn infrastructure spending and wider deficit respectively. Eur/Sek probed 10.4500 at one stage as Nok/Sek revisited very early 2019 troughs and Eur/Nok lagged within a 10.1400-10.1900 range amidst a mildly deeper retracement in crude prices on another unexpected weekly US inventory build. Back down under, Aud/Usd rebounded firmly from near 0.6800 lows to circa 0.6850 alongside (or just behind) Aud/Nzd to 1.0450 vs 1.0390 even though Nzd/Usd staged a late revival between 0.6564-24 parameters. 

GBP/CAD

Sterling endured another roller-coaster ride on the eve of the UK election after the eagerly anticipated YouGov MRP showed a sharp swing in voting intentions in favour of Labour and completely due to a decline in the number of seats predicted to be secured by the Conservatives. Cable retreated further from pre-poll peaks of 1.3200+ to just over 1.3100 before staging a firm recovery on 2 subsequent surveys keeping the Tory lead in double digits (percentage points-wise), while Eur/Gbp embarked on a round trip within 0.8463-11 extremes. Elsewhere, the Loonie got a belated boost to test 1.3200 resistance against its US rival and perhaps more follow-through from Tuesday’s USMCA draft accord, in line with the Mexican Peso.

CHF/EUR

The Franc succumbed to a bout of pre-SNB jitters ahead of Thursday’s quarterly policy meeting, wary that the Swiss Central Bank could conceivably upgrade its assessment of the Chf’s value from high, with Usd/Chf at the upper end of a 0.9863-42 band and Eur/Chf closer to 1.0940 than 1.0910. Meanwhile, the Euro edged a bit closer to 1.1100, but waned yet again in advance of tomorrow’s ECB that is tipped to be a quiet one in terms of new policy insight as Lagarde makes her debut. 

EM

One more ½ point BCB Selic rate cut and done vibes seemed to propel the Real up vs the Buck on top of a retail sales beat and the Rand maintained its Eskom-related rebound having shrugged off in line SA inflation and sub-consensus consumption figures, but the Lira lamented the return of US-Turkey angst instead of a below forecast current account balance.

subject: PRIMER: Brazil’s Central Bank Selic Rate decision is scheduled for release at 20:00 GMT/ 15:00 ET today, where analysts are looking for a fourth consecutive 50bp cut
analysis_details: • Brazil’s Central Bank Selic Rate decision is scheduled for release at 20:00 GMT/ 15:00 ET today, where analysts are looking for a fourth consecutive 50bp cut.  Some analysts are expecting the BCB to signal the end of the easing cycle -- short of this would be a dovish surprise. Desks think a '50bps cut and done' could be a positive for the BRL. Recently USDBRL has touched record lows causing the central bank to intervene in the FX market by selling dollars therefore any commentary surrounding the BRL weakness will be eyed. Analysts at IGM highlight that participants questioned whether further easing would be implemented after the recent intervention as the two are considered incompatible. Recent data has been strong, with GDP printing firmer than expected both M/M and Y/Y, which IGM highlights it initially saw some unwinding of market pricing for further easing in the future, although since the BRL has strengthened since the intervention, pricing returned to original levels and price in a 50bps cut for today and a further 25bps cut in February. November’s inflation was also firmer than expected at 3.27% Y/Y and 0.51% M/M, BCB’s current inflation targets are 4.25% for 2019, 4% for 2020, 3.75% for 2021 and 3.5% for 2022, however the bank allows a 1.5% leeway either side therefore currently CPI is sitting within the tolerance range of 2.75-5.75%.

subject: OPEC MONTHLY OIL REPORT (Dec): 2019 and 2020 oil demand growth remain unchanged; OPEC crude production in November fell
content:
• 2019 world oil demand growth forecast unchanged from the prior report at 980k BPD. In 2020, world oil demand is forecast to increase 1.08mln BPD Y/Y; unchanged from the prior report.
  • Preliminary data indicates that global oil supply in November increased by 410k BPD to average 99.78mln BPD (Prev. 99.78mln BPD)
  • Demand for OPEC crude for at 30.7mln BPD in 2019, unchanged from the prior report. 2020 also remains unchanged at 29.6mln BPD. Preliminary data imply that US oil demand will likely be solid throughout the remainder of this year.
  • OPEC crude production in November fell by 193k BPD to average 29.55mln BPD (Prev. 29.65mln BPD in October), according to secondary sources; oil output increased mostly in Ecuador, Kuwait and Libya, while production decreased in Saudi Arabia, Angola, Iraq and Iran
  • 2019 non-OPEC oil supply growth remains at 1.82mln BPD YY, unchanged from the prior release. In 2020, non-OPEC oil supply is projected to grow by 2.17mln BPD; unchanged
  • November Non-OPEC supply increased by 610k BPD to 70.22mln BPD, +1.28mln BPD YY. “Preliminary incremental production in November was mainly driven by the US, Canada, Norway, the UK, Russia, Azerbaijan and OPEC NGLs.”
  • OECD total products inventories fell in September by 23.9mln barrels MM to stand at 1.462bln barrels 47.8mln barrels above the same time a year ago, around 14.5mln above the latest 5yr average.
  • US crude exports averaged 3.0mln BPD in November, according to preliminary data, remaining above 3mln BPD for the third straight month, but some 0.2mln BPD or 5% lower compared with the previous month.
  • The share of OPEC crude oil in total global production decreased by 0.3ppts to 29.6% in November 2019 compared to the previous month.
  • The global economic growth forecast remains at 3.0% for both 2019 and 2020. Growth forecasts for all major regions (US, EZ, Japan, China, India) remain unchanged for 2019.
  • On trade, OPEC notes that global trade slowdown has likely bottomed out, and now the negative trend in industrial production seen in 2019 is expected to reverse in 2020.
analysis_details:
• There is a slight contrast to the EIA STEO, which saw 2019 world oil demand view unchanged, but raised its 2020 forecast by 50k BPD to 1.42mln BPD
  • OPEC believes that US oil demand will likely be solid throughout the remainder of the year, whilst EIA noted that US production will likely continue to grow as rig efficacy offsets declining rig activity
  • The OPEC report also notes that the cartel lost some market share, which sources previously noted was a concern among OPEC members when it came to cutting production

content: • Other reports suggest the retirement age has been increased to 64, however French PM Phillip added we will encourage people to work for longer with a discount and premium system.
analysis_details: French PM Philippe is presenting his pension reform proposal. France has seen mass industry-wide strikes against the proposals. The government has said it would see through planned reforms, but has tried to assuage anger by pledging to introduce the new system gradually. The plan aims to end special regimes under which some workers can retire in their early fifties, replacing it with a unified system with equal rights for everyone.

subject: Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 11th December 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses are mixed/flat at present, as newsflow remains light ahead of the impending risk events
  • White House Trade Advisor Navarro said China is trying to shape the narrative on trade talks and he believes the Dec 15th tariffs won’t come into effect
  • YouGov’s MRP model showed Conservatives are on track for a 28-seat majority vs. Prev. forecast of 68-seat majority
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US CPI, DoEs, US FOMC Rate Decision and Press Conference, OPEC Monthly Oil Report

ASIA-PAC

A non-committal tone persisted across Asia-Pac equity markets following conflicting US-China tariff reports and as this week’s risk events drew closer beginning with the FOMC meeting due later today. The latest trade headlines have been varied as initial reports suggested that US and Chinese officials are planning for a delay of December 15th tariffs as they negotiate on agricultural purchases, although President Trump was said to remain undecided and both NEC Director Kudlow and White House Trade Advisor Navarro have leaned back from the notion of a tariff postponement. This has resulted to mixed trade for ASX 200 (+0.7%) and Nikkei 225 (U/C) with Australia lifted by outperformance in the defensive sectors and price action in Tokyo kept to within a tight range as sentiment among large firms deteriorated to a 3-year low, while Hang Seng (+0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) were predominantly indecisive on the differing trade signals, with stronger than expected Chinese financing and lending data doing little to spur upside as participants also contemplated over continued PBoC liquidity inaction and regional growth downgrades from ADB which forecasts growth for the world’s 2nd largest economy to slip below 6% next year. Finally, 10yr JGBs saw a resumption of the recent declines following similar pressure in T-notes, while demand was also subdued by a lack of BoJ buying with the central bank only in the market today for treasury discount bills.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position PBoC set USD/CNY reference rate at 7.0385 vs. Exp. 7.0378 (Prev. 7.0400)

White House Trade Adviser Navarro said China is trying to shape the narrative on the trade talks and that he has no indication the December tariffs won't be put on, while he added it is President Trump's decision whether to delay the December 15th tariffs and the decision will come soon. (Newswires)

Chinese trade experts note that if US President Trump does not cancel planned tariffs on Chinese products on Dec 15th, it'll hurt US more than China, "China has digested the possibility and is well prepared to cope". (Newswires)

Asian Development Bank lowered China growth forecast for 2019 to 6.1% from 6.2% and cut 2020 growth forecast to 5.8% from 6.0%, while it forecasts Developing Asia growth at 5.2% for both 2019 and 2020. (Newswires) 

GEOPOLITICS

S&P have raised the possibility of a potential sovereign debt downgrade for India if growth does not improve. (Newswires)

South Korea will increase surveillance on North Korea preparations for the possible launch of an intercontinental ballistic missile. (Newswires)

Turkish Foreign Minister says if US sanctions Turkey over the Russian-made S-400 system, Turkey will retaliate, adds that Turkey is open to F-35 alternatives. (Newswires)

US

There were also comments from Canadian Deputy PM Freeland that all USMCA changes as well as the ratification of the deal ASAP are in Canada's interest, while Mexican Deputy Foreign Minister Seade stated that Mexico’s Senate may need until January to approve the USMCA changes. (Newswires/WSJ)

US federal judge blocked President Trump’s attempt to transfer USD 3.6bln of military construction funds to build the wall at border with Mexico. (Newswires)

UK/EU

YouGov MRP model showed Conservatives are on track for a 28-seat majority vs. Prev. forecast of 68-seat majority; Conservatives projected to win 339 seats vs. Prev. forecast 359 seats and Labour is on track to win 231 seats vs. Prev. forecast 211 seats. Furthermore, the model showed SNP at 41 (-2) Lib Dems 15 (+2), Brexit Party 0 (-) (Newswires) Note, the margin of error for the model could put the final seat tally for the Conservatives between 311 and 367, therefore suggesting that a hung Parliament is a possibility.

EQUITIES

A choppy session for European equities thus far [Eurostoxx 50 -0.2%] following on from a lacklustre APAC session heading into key macro risk events. Broad-based losses are seen across the board, albeit the FTSE 100 (-0.2%) is largely moving in tandem with the Pound ahead of tomorrow’s UK general election and after the latest MRP polling from YouGov. Sectors are mixed with Utilities propped up in part by Germany’s E.ON (+1.6%) and RWE (+0.7%) amid source reports that Germany will allow the companies to keep their existing carbon emissions certificates due to coal unit shutdowns. That said, the sector’s defensive nature could also be providing some support. Meanwhile, the IT sector is underperforms, potentially on trade jitters amid conflicting reports and rhetoric from both the US and China sides. In terms of individual movers – JD Sports Fashion (-8.7%) shares tumbled at the open after its top shareholder cut its stake in the company but retained his position as major shareholder. Credit Suisse (-0.5%) remains modestly pressured after it revised down its 2020 ROTE guidance to around 10% vs. Prev. 10-11%. On the flipside, Tullow Oil (+5.6%) continues to nurse its wounds following its recent 70% slump, whilst Inditex (+2.7%) is buoyed post-earnings, which showed an YY gains in net profit, net sales, EBITDA and gross profits.

Saudi Aramco shares open at SAR 35.2 vs. SAR 32 IPO price. (Newswires)

FX

SEK/GBP - Not quite polar opposites, but contrasting fortunes for the Swedish Krona and Sterling in wake of inflation data and the final pre-UK election poll from YouGov, as the former eclipsed market expectations and matched Riksbank forecasts to effectively seal a repo rate hike next week. However, the MRP survey implies a much tighter result this Thursday than the previous findings, with a projected Tory majority of 28 seats vs 68 seats around the end of November and even that prediction subject to the usual margins of error. In response, Eur/Sek has recoiled sharply to test 10.4500 support vs highs close to 10.5400 and 10.5800+ on Tuesday, while Cable has pulled back from just over 1.3200 to circa 1.3140 after probing bids ahead of 1.3100 and Eur/Gbp bounced through 0.8450 at one stage before fading.

AUD/NZD - A similar story down under where the tables have turned somewhat on the back of a reversal in cross flows following the latest NZ Half Year Fiscal update revealing a bigger cash balance shortfall and fresh Nzd12 bn budget allocation for infrastructure. Nzd/Usd has lost momentum after a knee-jerk rally to around 0.6555 and Aud/Nzd rebounded from sub-1.0400 towards 1.0450 to help Aud/Usd maintain 0.6800+ status even though RBC joined the chorus for more RBA easing and QE.

JPY/CAD/CHF/EUR - All narrowly mixed against the Greenback as the DXY continues to straddle the 97.500 level in relatively muted/nervy trade awaiting the FOMC, with the Yen meandering between 108.67-84 parameters, Loonie trapped in a 1.3227-39 range and Franc pivoting 0.9850. Elsewhere, the Euro is still looking heavy or toppy into 1.1100 and perhaps conscious that a hefty 1.6 bn option expiries reside from the big figure to 1.1110, not to mention the fact that tomorrow is ECB (and SNB) day.

EM - Divergence also a theme in terms of Rand outperformance compared to Lira underperformance, as Usd/Zar pares back from almost 14.8200 in wake of in line/softer than previous SA CPI on less Eskom load-shedding before attention turns to retail sales data, but Usd/Try hovers around 5.8000 due to renewed US-Turkey sanctions and diplomatic tension rather than a slightely narrower than anticipated current account surplus.

New Zealand Budget Cash Balance (Jul) -5.154B (Prev. -2.785B). (Newswires) New Zealand Net Debt Forecast (Jul) 19.6% (Prev. 20.1%) New Zealand OBEGAL Forecast (Jul) -0.943B (Prev. 3.465B)

New Zealand announced NZD 12bln of new infrastructure spending and sees 2019/20 GDP at 2.3% vs. Prev. 3.2%, while it added that although domestic economy is slowing it is still outperforming global peers. (Newswires)

Swedish CPIF YY (Nov) 1.7% vs. Exp. 1.6% (Prev. 1.5%); CPIF MM (Nov) 0.1% (Prev. 0.0%)

Large FX Option Expiries, NY Cut:

-        EUR/USD: 1.1050-55 (500M), 1.1075 (450M), 1.1100-10 (1.6BLN)  

-        GBP/USD: 1.3150-60 (700M), 1.3185 (310M), 1.3195-1.3205 (600M)

-        USD/JPY: 107.85 (430M), 107.95-108.00 (1.3BLN), 108.75-85 (750M), 109.00 (1.3BLN), 109.50 (811M)

FIXED INCOME

The latest advances have been more measured, but from a chart or technical perspective no less telling as Bunds notch a new wtd and post-NFP peak at 172.67, while Gilts get extremely close on pre-UK vote positioning after YouGov’s MRP at 131.96. However, US Treasuries appear a bit more reticent/lethargic in wake of a so-so/mediocre 10 year auction and awaiting inflation data that forms the appetiser before Wednesday’s main course and headline Fed event.

Saudi Arabia plans to issue USD 32bln in debt in 2020; 45% international and 55% local, according to the head of the Saudi DMO. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES 

Mixed trade in the commodities complex with WTI and Brent futures retreating from 12-week highs following last night’s weekly API figures – with crude headline printing a surprise build of 1.41mln barrels vs. expected draw of 2.8mln. Further, the internals came in mostly bearish with distillates and gasoline showing higher-than-forecast builds whilst Cushing printed a deeper-than-expected draw. Traders will be waiting for confirmation from the EIA later today. Meanwhile OPEC’s monthly report (to be released at 13:00GMT) may garner some attention given the EIA STEO left its global oil demand forecast unchanged and included a downward revision to their 2020 US oil supply growth forecast. ING is not surprised by the downward revision given the slowdown seen in US rig activity. In terms of a more macro picture, crude markets will be vulnerable to any US-China headlines amid the contradicting reports regarding tariffs due to be implemented this Sunday. Aside from that, the FOMC’s latest monetary policy decision later could provide the complex with some sentiment-driven action. Today also marked the first trading session for Saudi Aramco, whose shares opened at SAR 35.2 vs. and IPO price of SAR 32.0, hitting limit up after rising 10% and surpassing its earlier valuation of USD 1.7tln. Looking at metals, spot gold prices remain supported ahead of the aforementioned events, with the yellow metal surpassing its 21DMA (USD 1465.50/oz) with eyes on yesterday’s high at USD 1469.15/oz. Copper prices continue to rise and have topped 2.75/lb with its 100 DMA residing around 2.8060/lb. Finally, nickel prices came under pressure in early APAC trade after inventories spiked 21% YY, the largest increase since 2008, but despite this the metal reversed course with the only pertinent news being Indonesia doubling royalties for the ore to 10% - making it more expensive for buyers, thus some front-loading effects may have been priced in.

US API Inventories: Crude +1.41mln vs. Exp. -2.8mln (Prev. -3.7mln). (Newswires)

EU heads of state or government will discuss a proposed budget of EUR 1.087trln for 2021-2027, equal to 1.07% of the gross national income of EU member states.

On the flipside, Tullow Oil (+5.6%) continues to nurse its wounds following its recent 70% slump, whilst Inditex (+2.7%) is buoyed post-earnings, which showed an YY gains in net profit, net sales, EBITDA and gross profits.

FX

SEK/GBP - Not quite polar opposites, but contrasting fortunes for the Swedish Krona and Sterling in wake of inflation data and the final pre-UK election poll from YouGov, as the former eclipsed market expectations and matched Riksbank forecasts to effectively seal a repo rate hike next week. However, the MRP survey implies a much tighter result this Thursday than the previous findings, with a projected Tory majority of 28 seats vs 68 seats around the end of November and even that prediction subject to the usual margins of error. In response, Eur/Sek has recoiled sharply to test 10.4500 support vs highs close to 10.5400 and 10.5800+ on Tuesday, while Cable has pulled back from just over 1.3200 to circa 1.3140 after probing bids ahead of 1.3100 and Eur/Gbp bounced through 0.8450 at one stage before fading.

AUD/NZD - A similar story down under where the tables have turned somewhat on the back of a reversal in cross flows following the latest NZ Half Year Fiscal update revealing a bigger cash balance shortfall and fresh Nzd12 bn budget allocation for infrastructure. Nzd/Usd has lost momentum after a knee-jerk rally to around 0.6555 and Aud/Nzd rebounded from sub-1.0400 towards 1.0450 to help Aud/Usd maintain 0.6800+ status even though RBC joined the chorus for more RBA easing and QE.

JPY/CAD/CHF/EUR - All narrowly mixed against the Greenback as the DXY continues to straddle the 97.500 level in relatively muted/nervy trade awaiting the FOMC, with the Yen meandering between 108.67-84 parameters, Loonie trapped in a 1.3227-39 range and Franc pivoting 0.9850. Elsewhere, the Euro is still looking heavy or toppy into 1.1100 and perhaps conscious that a hefty 1.6 bn option expiries reside from the big figure to 1.1110, not to mention the fact that tomorrow is ECB (and SNB) day.

EM - Divergence also a theme in terms of Rand outperformance compared to Lira underperformance, as Usd/Zar pares back from almost 14.8200 in wake of in line/softer than previous SA CPI on less Eskom load-shedding before attention turns to retail sales data, but Usd/Try hovers around 5.8000 due to renewed US-Turkey sanctions and diplomatic tension rather than a slightely narrower than anticipated current account surplus.

FIXED INCOME

The latest advances have been more measured, but from a chart or technical perspective no less telling as Bunds notch a new wtd and post-NFP peak at 172.67, while Gilts get extremely close on pre-UK vote positioning after YouGov’s MRP at 131.96. However, US Treasuries appear a bit more reticent/lethargic in wake of a so-so/mediocre 10 year auction and awaiting inflation data that forms the appetiser before Wednesday’s main course and headline Fed event.

COMMODITIES 

Mixed trade in the commodities complex with WTI and Brent futures retreating from 12-week highs following last night’s weekly API figures – with crude headline printing a surprise build of 1.41mln barrels vs. expected draw of 2.8mln. Further, the internals came in mostly bearish with distillates and gasoline showing higher-than-forecast builds whilst Cushing printed a deeper-than-expected draw. Traders will be waiting for confirmation from the EIA later today. Meanwhile OPEC’s monthly report (to be released at 13:00GMT) may garner some attention given the EIA STEO left its global oil demand forecast unchanged and included a downward revision to their 2020 US oil supply growth forecast. ING is not surprised by the downward revision given the slowdown seen in US rig activity. In terms of a more macro picture, crude markets will be vulnerable to any US-China headlines amid the contradicting reports regarding tariffs due to be implemented this Sunday. Aside from that, the FOMC’s latest monetary policy decision later could provide the complex with some sentiment-driven action. Today also marked the first trading session for Saudi Aramco, whose shares opened at SAR 35.2 vs. and IPO price of SAR 32.0, hitting limit up after rising 10% and surpassing its earlier valuation of USD 1.7tln. Looking at metals, spot gold prices remain supported ahead of the aforementioned events, with the yellow metal surpassing its 21DMA (USD 1465.50/oz) with eyes on yesterday’s high at USD 1469.15/oz. Copper prices continue to rise and have topped 2.75/lb with its 100 DMA residing around 2.8060/lb. Finally, nickel prices came under pressure in early APAC trade after inventories spiked 21% YY, the largest increase since 2008, but despite this the metal reversed course with the only pertinent news being Indonesia doubling royalties for the ore to 10% - making it more expensive for buyers, thus some front-loading effects may have been priced in.

Newsquawk Ad-Hoc Economic Analysis - PREVIEW: 2019 UK General Election – 12th December 2019 (2nd Edition)
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

After failing to secure the passage of PM Johnson’s Brexit deal through Parliament and subsequently having to request an extension of the Article 50 deadline to January 31st, MPs opted to send UK voters to the polls once again in order to break the political stalemate. The vote will take place on 12th December 2019 with votes cast between 0700-2200GMT; an exit poll will be released immediately thereafter. Votes will be counted once polls have closed with individual seat results released throughout the night and the final outcome to be announced on Friday 13th December.

Bunds: back up towards recent highs in tentative pre-FOMC trade
content: The 10 year German benchmark has embarked on another ascent from lows posted prior to the start of EU trading, but the rebound is fragile again amidst relatively muted volumes and a typically cautious tone ahead of the Fed. Indeed, the latest recovery high has fallen short of previous peaks achieved so far this week, at 172.44, albeit with the aforementioned base also shallower than yesterday’s trough. Bunds could derive some added impetus from Gilts in wake of pre-UK election factors, but in truth price action may well be choppy all the way through to the Fed.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

11th December 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the   overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

A non-committal tone persisted across Asia-Pac equity markets following conflicting US-China tariff reports and as this week’s risk events drew closer beginning with the FOMC meeting due later today. The latest trade headlines have been varied as initial reports suggested that US and Chinese officials are planning for a delay of December 15th tariffs as they negotiate on agricultural purchases, although President Trump was said to remain undecided and both NEC Director Kudlow and White House Trade Advisor Navarro have leaned back from the notion of a tariff postponement. This has resulted to mixed trade for ASX 200 (+0.7%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) with Australia lifted by outperformance in the defensive sectors and price action in Tokyo kept to within a tight range as sentiment among large firms deteriorated to a 3-year low, while Hang Seng (+0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) were predominantly indecisive on the differing trade signals, with stronger than expected Chinese financing and lending data doing little to spur upside as participants also contemplated over continued PBoC liquidity inaction and regional growth downgrades from ADB which forecasts growth for the world’s 2nd largest economy to slip below 6% next year.

Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 11th December 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • A non-committal tone persisted across Asia-Pac equity markets following conflicting US-China trade headlines
  • White House Trade Adviser Navarro said he has no indication the December tariffs won't be put on
  • YouGov MRP model showed Conservatives are on track for a 28-seat majority vs. Prev. forecast of 68-seat majority
  • GBP lagged, USD eked mild gains ahead of the FOMC policy announcement, EUR/USD was contained just shy of 1.1100
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Swedish and US CPI, DoEs, US FOMC Rate Decision and Press Conference, OPEC Monthly Oil Report

ASIA-PAC

A non-committal tone persisted across Asia-Pac equity markets following conflicting US-China tariff reports and as this week’s risk events drew closer beginning with the FOMC meeting due later today. The latest trade headlines have been varied as initial reports suggested that US and Chinese officials are planning for a delay of December 15th tariffs as they negotiate on agricultural purchases, although President Trump was said to remain undecided and both NEC Director Kudlow and White House Trade Advisor Navarro have leaned back from the notion of a tariff postponement. This has resulted to mixed trade for ASX 200 (+0.7%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) with Australia lifted by outperformance in the defensive sectors and price action in Tokyo kept to within a tight range as sentiment among large firms deteriorated to a 3-year low, while Hang Seng (+0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) were predominantly indecisive on the differing trade signals, with stronger than expected Chinese financing and lending data doing little to spur upside as participants also contemplated over continued PBoC liquidity inaction and regional growth downgrades from ADB which forecasts growth for the world’s 2nd largest economy to slip below 6% next year. Finally, 10yr JGBs saw a resumption of the recent declines following similar pressure in T-notes, while demand was also subdued by a lack of BoJ buying with the central bank only in the market today for treasury discount bills.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position PBoC set USD/CNY reference rate at 7.0385 vs. Exp. 7.0378 (Prev. 7.0400)

White House Trade Adviser Navarro said China is trying to shape the narrative on the trade talks and that he has no indication the December tariffs won't be put on, while he added it is President Trump's decision whether to delay the December 15th tariffs and the decision will come soon. (Newswires)

China Global Times Editor Hu Xijin suggested that the principle of the Chinese government is that as long as the US takes real action that harms China's interests, Beijing will definitely take countermeasures and make US side pay the due price. (Twitter)

Asian Development Bank lowered China growth forecast for 2019 to 6.1% from 6.2% and cut 2020 growth forecast to 5.8% from 6.0%, while it forecasts Developing Asia growth at 5.2% for both 2019 and 2020. (Newswires) 

UK/EU

YouGov MRP model showed Conservatives are on track for a 28-seat majority vs. Prev. forecast of 68-seat majority; Conservatives projected to win 339 seats vs. Prev. forecast 359 seats and Labour is on track to win 231 seats vs. Prev. forecast 211 seats. Furthermore, the model showed SNP at 41 (-2) Lib Dems 15 (+2), Brexit Party 0 (-) (Newswires) Note, the margin of error for the model could put the final seat tally for the Conservatives between 311 and 367, therefore suggesting that a hung Parliament is a possibility.

 

Focaldata MRP model showed Conservatives at 337 seats, Labour 235, SNP 41, Lib Dems 14, Brexit Party 0, which puts the Conservative majority at 24. (Newswires)

 

FX

In FX markets, GBP/USD underperformed with the pullback from the 1.3200 handle exacerbated after the highly anticipated YouGov MRP model projected a narrower majority win for PM Johnson’s Conservatives who are on track to win 339 seats (-20) vs. Labour at 231 seats (+20) for a 28-seat majority vs. Prev. 68-seat majority at the November 27th projection, while reports also noted that 36 seats are to be determined by a slim margin of just 3% or lower. This pressured GBP/USD to take out several key moving average levels and briefly below its 100 hourly moving average but has since found mild solace with the losses eventually stemmed by support a tad north of the 1.3100 level. Elsewhere, the DXY eked mild gains but with price action stalled around 97.50 as participants await today’s FOMC and EUR/USD was also contained just shy of 1.1100, although EUR/GBP was buoyed momentarily through 0.8450 upon the UK election projection announcement. USD/JPY and JPY-crosses were uneventful due to the mixed risk sentiment which kept antipodeans indecisive, with NZD also choppy after the Half-Year and Economic Fiscal Update showed a larger budget deficit projection due to higher spending and which initially lifted the currency as it essentially reduces the need for further RBNZ cuts, although these gains were eventually faded.

New Zealand Budget Cash Balance (Jul) -5.154B (Prev. -2.785B). (Newswires) New Zealand Net Debt Forecast (Jul) 19.6% (Prev. 20.1%) New Zealand OBEGAL Forecast (Jul) -0.943B (Prev. 3.465B)

New Zealand announced NZD 12bln of new infrastructure spending and sees 2019/20 GDP at 2.3% vs. Prev. 3.2%, while it added that although domestic economy is slowing it is still outperforming global peers. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were subdued with WTI crude futures languishing below the USD 59.00/bbl after US officials downplayed the suggestions of a potential delay in the looming US-China tariffs, with prices also weighed following a bearish API report which showed a surprise build in headline crude inventories and almost double than anticipated build for gasoline stockpiles. Elsewhere, price action in gold was restricted by the mild gains in the greenback and with participants sidelined ahead of today’s FOMC, while copper plateaued amid the broad overnight indecision.  

US API Inventories: Crude +1.41mln vs. Exp. -2.8mln (Prev. -3.7mln). (Newswires) EIA Short-Term Energy Outlook sees 2019 world oil demand growth unchanged at 0.75mln BPD and 2020 forecast was raised by 50k BPD to 1.42mln BPD Y/Y increase. EIA added it expects US crude oil production to average 13.2mln BPD in 2020 (+0.9mln BPD vs 2019 levels which is slower than 2018 growth of 1.6mln BPD and 2019 growth of 1.3mln BPD, while it forecasts OPEC crude oil production will average 29.3mln BPD in 2020 which is down 0.5mln BPD vs 2019. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

South Korea will increase surveillance on North Korea preparations for the possible launch of an intercontinental ballistic missile. (Newswires)

 

US Secretary of State Pompeo believes there will be a significant announcement on US-Russia economic ties in the not-so-distant future, while he also commented that China needs to be included in arms control treaty and the scope of talks should be broadened. (Newswires) 

US 

T-notes were in the ascendency, at the start of the day, with a bull-flattening bias, before a positive WSJ report on US/China trade saw sellers emerge; however, Treasuries pared losses, as other asset classes did as the report was digested. The US auction of 10-year notes was decent, stopping through the screens by 0.1bps, while cover was a touch firmer than recent averages. Indirect participation was a little softer than recent averages, and like the 3s auction on Monday, direct bidders' participation was firmer. The US will sell 30-year bonds ahead of the FOMC announcement. At settlement, yields were slightly higher on the day across the curve, though major curve spreads had still narrowed by 1-2bps. US T-note (H0) futures settled 1+ ticks lower at 128-29+.

USTR Lighthizer confirmed a USMCA agreement has been reached and stated that the USMCA will be the model for US trade deals going forward. There were also comments from Canadian Deputy PM Freeland that all USMCA changes as well as the ratification of the deal ASAP are in Canada's interest, while Mexican Deputy Foreign Minister Seade stated that Mexico’s Senate may need until January to approve the USMCA changes and US Senate Majority Leader McConnell also suggested the USMCA deal will not be taken up by the Senate next week but likely after the Trump impeachment trial as he hopes to deal with the defense and spending bills next week ahead of the recess. (Newswires/WSJ)

US House Speaker Pelosi said the US is not going to have a shutdown and will be funded through till next year. (Newswires)

subject: ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Mixed tariff-related signals and looming FOMC kept Asia-Pac trade indecisive
content: A non-committal tone persisted across Asia-Pac equity markets following conflicting US-China tariff reports and as this week’s risk events drew closer beginning with the FOMC meeting due later today. The latest trade headlines have been varied as initial reports suggested that US and Chinese officials are planning for a delay of December 15th tariffs as they negotiate on agricultural purchases, although President Trump was said to remain undecided and both NEC Director Kudlow and White House Trade Advisor Navarro have leaned back from the notion of a tariff postponement. This has resulted to mixed trade for ASX 200 (+0.7%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) with Australia lifted by outperformance in the defensive sectors and price action in Tokyo kept to within a tight range as sentiment among large firms deteriorated to a 3-year low, while Hang Seng (+0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) were predominantly indecisive on the differing trade signals, with stronger than expected Chinese financing and lending data doing little to spur upside as participants also contemplated over continued PBoC liquidity inaction and regional growth downgrades from ADB which forecasts growth for the world’s 2nd largest economy to slip below 6% next year. Finally, 10yr JGBs saw a resumption of the recent declines following similar pressure in T-notes, while demand was also subdued by a lack of BoJ buying with the central bank only in the market today for treasury discount bills.

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Mixed tariff headlines and looming FOMC keeps Asia stocks cautious
content:
A non-committal tone persists across Asia-Pac equity markets following conflicting US-China tariff reports and as this week’s risk events draw near beginning with the FOMC meeting due later today. The latest trade headlines have been varied as initial reports suggested that US and Chinese officials are planning for a delay of December 15th tariffs as they negotiate on agricultural purchases, although President Trump was said to remain undecided and both NEC Director Kudlow and White House Trade Advisor Navarro have leaned back from the notion of a tariff postponement. This has resulted to mixed trade for ASX 200 (+0.4%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) but with price action kept to within tight ranges, while Hang Seng (+0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) are also indecisive on the differing trade signals, with stronger than expected Chinese financing and lending data doing little to spur upside as participants also contemplate over continued PBoC liquidity inaction and regional growth downgrades from ADB which sees growth for the world’s 2nd largest economy to slip below 6% next year.

In FX markets, GBP/USD underperforms with the pullback from the 1.3200 handle exacerbated after the highly anticipated YouGov MRP model projected a narrower majority win for PM Johnson’s Conservatives who are on track to win 339 seats (-20) vs. Labour at 231 seats (+20) for just a 28-seat majority vs. Prev. 68-seat majority at the November 27th projection, while reports also noted that 36 seats are to be determined by a slim margin of just 3% or lower. This pressured GBP/USD to take out several key moving average levels and briefly below its 100 hourly moving average but has since found mild solace with the losses eventually stemmed by support a tad north of the 1.3100 level. Elsewhere, the DXY eked mild gains but with price action stalled around 97.50 as participants await today’s FOMC and EUR/USD is also quiet as it bides its time just shy of 1.1100, although EUR/GBP was buoyed briefly through 0.8450 upon the UK election projection announcement. USD/JPY and JPY-crosses are uneventful due to the mixed risk sentiment which has also kept antipodeans indecisive, with NZD also choppy after the Half-Year and Economic Fiscal Update showed a larger budget deficit projection due to higher spending and which initially lifted the currency as it essentially reduces the need for further RBNZ cuts, although these gains were eventually faded.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower on resumption of the recent downside and following weakness in T-notes, while demand is also subdued by a lack of BoJ buying with the central bank only in the market today for treasury discount bills.

PRE-MARKET CHINESE STOCK NEWS: Conflicting tariff-delay reports; Chinese lending and financing data topped estimates
content:
HSBC (5 HK) - Co. to pay USD 192mln to settle US tax probe, while the Co. was also said to have taken a step closer to offloading its retail bank in France. (Newswires)

Shenzhen Yantian Port Holding (000088 CH) - Co. unit is planning to invest CNY 1.8bln in 3rd phase of port project. (Newswires)

Visionox (002387 CH) - Co. unit agrees to sell 51% stake in electronics firm for CNY 122.4mln. (Newswires)

Pharmaceuticals - China is to begin bulk drug purchases in 2 months in which drugs purchased through the bulk program may see price cuts of more than 50%. (China Securities Journal)

Defaults - Fitch anticipates Chinese corporate bond defaults to surge to a record high next year as government bailouts are no longer guaranteed. (SCMP)

Other News - An undisclosed foreign sovereign fund is to invest USD 3bln in the Chinese stock market. (Newswires) 

 

Trade

US and Chinese officials are reportedly planning for a delay of December 15th tariffs as they haggle on how to get Beijing to commit to large purchases of US farm products Trump is insisting on for a near term deal, although President Trump remains undecided, according to WSJ citing sources. (WSJ)

NEC Director Kudlow said he cannot confirm the December 15th China tariff delay and noted that the reality is December 15th tariffs are still on the table, while he added China's demand to roll back tariffs is also part of the talks. Kudlow also stated that US President Trump's call to do the deal in phases improved the outlook and that China trade and human rights issues are separate tracks. (Newswires)

US White House Trade Adviser Navarro said China is trying to shape the narrative on the trade talks and that he has no indication the December tariffs won't be put on, while he added it is President Trump's decision on delaying the December 15th tariffs and the decision will come soon. (Newswires)

US Commerce Secretary Ross said it is more important to get a good deal for US when asked if the December 15th tariffs will take effect, while he added the US is having good discussions with China on IP and that phase one deal will largely be about agriculture and trade. (Newswires)

White House Chief of Staff Mulvaney said the trajectory toward a phase one deal is pretty good, according to a CNBC reporter. (Twitter)

China Global Times Editor Hu Xijin suggested that the principle of the Chinese government is that as long as the US takes real action that harms China's interests, Beijing will definitely take countermeasures and make US side pay the due price. (Twitter)

Global Times tweeted that Japan Coast Guard reportedly plans to remove Chinese drone maker DJI from its procurement list under the guise of information security. (Twitter)

 

Data Recap

  • Chinese Aggregate Financing (CNY)(Nov) 1750B vs. Exp. 1485.0B (Prev. 618.9B)
  • Chinese New Yuan Loans (CNY)(Nov) 1390B vs. Exp. 1200.0B (Prev. 661.3B)
  • Chinese M2 Money Supply (Nov) Y/Y 8.2% vs. Exp. 8.4% (Prev. 8.4%)
